crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detect the PowerShell based downloader used by APT42 called NEWSTERMINAL
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Sekoia.io

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: APP-DETECT SSH server detected on non-standard port
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp $EXTERNAL_NET !22 -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"APP-DETECT SSH server detected on non-standard port"; flow:to_client,established; content:"SSH-",depth 4,nocase; pcre:"/^SSH-[12]\.\d+/ims"; reference:url,www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4251.txt; classtype:protocol-command-decode; gid:1; sid:13586; rev:6; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET USER_AGENTS Go HTTP Client User-Agent
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET USER_AGENTS Go HTTP Client User-Agent"; flow:established,to_server; http.user_agent; content:"Go-http-client"; nocase; fast_pattern; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2024897; rev:3; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2017_10_23, deployment Perimeter, confidence High, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2024_06_13;)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects usage of the netsh command to open and allow connections to port 3389 (RDP). As seen used by Sarwent Malware

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=netsh.exe; Hashes=MD5=6F1E6DD688818BC3D1391D0CC7D597EB,SHA256=6B691B06FA865F52C9484EF4F10E2E02ED6D7C3A3F474B8B138A33AF7258B2A9,IMPHASH=90B4317BE51850B8EF9F14EB56FB7DDC; Description=Network Command Shell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\sysnative\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy bypass -File "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\sample.ps1"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\netsh.exe" advfirewall firewall add rule name=RemoteDesktopTCP-In3389 dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=3389; FileVersion=10.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\netsh.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential WinAPI Calls Via PowerShell Scripts
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects use of WinAPI functions in PowerShell scripts
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems), Nikita Nazarov, oscd.community

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=Set-StrictMode -Version 2.0

<#
    .Synopsis
    Get-UserSID
#>
function Get-UserSID
{       
    [CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName='User')]
    param
        (   [parameter(Mandatory=$true, ParameterSetName="User")]
            [ValidateNotNull()]
            [System.Security.Principal.NTAccount]$User,
            [parameter(Mandatory=$true, ParameterSetName="WellKnownSidType")]
            [ValidateNotNull()]
            [System.Security.Principal.WellKnownSidType]$WellKno [TRUNCATED]; MessageTotal=5; ScriptBlockId=50e25686-80ac-4743-94b5-131862af00c1; Path=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\OpenSSHUtils.psm1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Dot net compiler compiles file from suspicious location
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Dot net compiler compiles file from suspicious location

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae .NET Framework; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=csc.exe; Hashes=SHA1=93CF877F5627E55EC076A656E935042FAC39950E,MD5=23EE3D381CFE3B9F6229483E2CE2F9E1,SHA256=4240A12E0B246C9D69AF1F697488FE7DA1B497DF20F4A6F95135B4D5FE180A57,IMPHASH=EE1E569AD02AA1F7AECA80AC0601D80D; Description=Visual C# Command Line Compiler; FileVersion=4.8.3761.0 built by: NET48REL1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\install-sshd.ps1 ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\csc.exe" /noconfig /fullpaths @"C:\Users\george\AppData\Local\Temp\25ryezej\25ryezej.cmdline"; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\csc.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the use of Ngrok, a utility used for port forwarding and tunneling, often used by threat actors to make local protected services publicly available.
Involved domains are bin.equinox.io for download and *.ngrok.io for connections.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=D3A23B8C9E125CFC6BAE2D6006FF406F3C02C4CD,MD5=60ADBB2A2AA829C0EF7BBFCE5214FF82,SHA256=98FB12A9625D600535DF342551D30B27ED216FED14D9C6F63E8BF677CB730301,IMPHASH=07361A3A7F515BF56CA93120B2ACA73B; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; Product=ngrok agent; Description=The ngrok agent gets you online in one line.; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -noLogo -ExecutionPolicy unrestricted -file "C:\Users\george\Desktop\script.ps1"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\vmspolicyservice.exe" tcp 3389 ; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\vmspolicyservice.exe}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Hiding User Account Via SpecialAccounts Registry Key
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects modifications to the registry key "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\Userlist" where the value is set to "0" in order to hide user account from being listed on the logon screen.

match_context.values: @{Details=DWORD (0x00000000); EventType=SetValue; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=13; TargetObject=HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\Userlist\jackson}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Outbound RDP Connections Over Non-Standard Tools
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects Non-Standard tools initiating a connection over port 3389 indicating possible lateral movement.
An initial baseline is required before using this utility to exclude third party RDP tooling that you might use.

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=3389; Initiated=true; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=127.0.0.1; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49721; Image=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\ssh.exe; DestinationIp=127.0.0.1}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=3389; Initiated=true; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=127.0.0.1; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\ssh.exe; SourcePort=49724; DestinationIp=127.0.0.1}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=3389; DestinationIp=127.0.0.1; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=127.0.0.1; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; Image=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\ssh.exe; SourcePort=49727; Initiated=true}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=3389; DestinationIp=127.0.0.1; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=127.0.0.1; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49728; Image=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\ssh.exe; Initiated=true}

@{SourceIsIpv6=false; DestinationPort=3389; DestinationIp=127.0.0.1; Protocol=tcp; SourceIp=127.0.0.1; DestinationIsIpv6=false; EventID=3; SourcePort=49730; Image=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\ssh.exe; Initiated=true}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Tampering With RDP Related Registry Keys Via Reg.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of "reg.exe" for enabling/disabling the RDP service on the host by tampering with the 'CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server' values

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=reg.exe; Hashes=MD5=227F63E1D9008B36BDBCC4B397780BE4,SHA256=C0E25B1F9B22DE445298C1E96DDFCEAD265CA030FA6626F61A4A4786CC4A3B7D,IMPHASH=BE482BE427FE212CFEF2CDA0E61F19AC; Description=Registry Console Tool; FileVersion=10.0.19041.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\sysnative\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy bypass -File "C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\sample.ps1"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\reg.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{Hashes=SHA1=04CE0B79EA20332CC4FF4679883B18BFE4341FBD,MD5=E3DACF0B31841FA02064B4457D44B357,SHA256=928693D84D652DC15B3FCDC6576D790053755C5181CE6708B1110DE12ADAE4A1,IMPHASH=BE482BE427FE212CFEF2CDA0E61F19AC; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\george\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=reg.exe; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Registry Console Tool; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -noLogo -ExecutionPolicy unrestricted -file "C:\Users\george\Desktop\script.ps1"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\reg.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}
@{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe add HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Tampering With RDP Related Registry Keys Via Reg.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of "reg.exe" for enabling/disabling the RDP service on the host by tampering with the 'CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server' values

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects creation of a local user via PowerShell

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "-ExecutionPolicy" flag.

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\install-sshd.ps1; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.
Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are
used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to
load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: User Added to Local Administrator Group
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the addition of a new member to the local administrator group, which could be legitimate activity or a sign of privilege escalation activity

match_context.values: @{SubjectUserSid=S-1-5-21-4270068108-2931534202-3907561125-1001; TargetDomainName=Builtin; TargetUserName=Administrators; MemberSid=S-1-5-21-4270068108-2931534202-3907561125-1006; EventID=4732; TargetSid=S-1-5-32-544; SubjectLogonId=68959; SubjectUserName=azure; SubjectDomainName=azure-PC}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Netsh Allow Group Policy on Microsoft Defender Firewall
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Adversaries may modify system firewalls in order to bypass controls limiting network usage

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain access to victim systems.
Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Hiding User Account Via SpecialAccounts Registry Key - CommandLine
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changes to the registry key "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\Userlist" where the value is set to "0" in order to hide user account from being listed on the logon screen.

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\Userlist" /v jackson /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: RDP Sensitive Settings Changed to Zero
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects tampering of RDP Terminal Service/Server sensitive settings.
Such as allowing unauthorized users access to a system via the 'fAllowUnsolicited' or enabling RDP via 'fDenyTSConnections', etc.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Samir Bousseaden, David ANDRE, Roberto Rodriguez @Cyb3rWard0g, Nasreddine Bencherchali

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: PowerShell Script With File Upload Capabilities
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell scripts leveraging the "Invoke-WebRequest" cmdlet to send data via either "PUT" or "POST" method.
Detects local user creation on Windows servers, which shouldn't happen in an Active Directory environment. Apply this Sigma Use Case on your Windows server logs and not on your DC logs.

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=Set-StrictMode -Version 2.0

<#
    .Synopsis
    Get-UserSID
#>
function Get-UserSID
{       
    [CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName='User')]
    param
        (   [parameter(Mandatory=$true, ParameterSetName="User")]
            [ValidateNotNull()]
            [System.Security.Principal.NTAccount]$User,
            [parameter(Mandatory=$true, ParameterSetName="WellKnownSidType")]
            [ValidateNotNull()]
            [System.Security.Principal.WellKnownSidType]$WellKno [TRUNCATED]; Path=C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\OpenSSHUtils.psm1; ScriptBlockId=50e25686-80ac-4743-94b5-131862af00c1; MessageTotal=5; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The code snippet is a PowerShell script that performs several actions, including:

* Creating a New User: It creates a new local user account named "jackson" with a specific password and elevates it to the "Administrators" group.
* Configuring Firewall: It enables the Windows Firewall and adds a rule to allow incoming TCP traffic on port 3389, which is commonly used for Remote Desktop Services.
* Configuring Terminal Services: It modifies registry settings related to Terminal Services, likely enabling or modifying its configuration.
* Downloading and Extracting Files: It downloads three ZIP files from a remote URL and extracts their contents to specific locations:
    * "sfile.zip" to "C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH"
    * "sconfig.zip" to "C:\ProgramData\ssh"
    * "vmspolicyservice.zip" to "C:\Windows"
* Executing a Script: It executes a PowerShell script located at "C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\install-sshd.ps1".
* Starting a Service: It starts the "sshd" service.
* Configuring a Service: It uses a command-line tool named "vmspolicyservice.exe" with arguments "config add-authtoken" and "tcp 3389", potentially configuring a service related to Remote Desktop Services.
* Sending a Post Request: It sends a POST request to a URL "https://s3api.shop/api/btnsendngip2024.php" with data including a public IP address and a news identifier.
* Establishing SSH Tunnels: It establishes three SSH tunnels to a remote host "190.2.150.50" on port 443, forwarding ports 21221, 21222, and 21223.
* Downloading and Replacing a DLL: It downloads a ZIP file containing a DLL named "termsrvx64.dll" from a remote URL, extracts it to a temporary directory, and replaces the existing "termsrv.dll" file in the "System32" directory with the downloaded one.
* Cleaning up: It deletes the temporary directory used for downloading and extracting files.

The script uses functions to perform various tasks, including:

* Ensure-FolderExists: Ensures that a specified directory exists.
* Download-And-Extract-Dll: Downloads a ZIP file, extracts a specific DLL from it, replaces the original DLL in the "System32" directory with the new one, and grants permissions to the new DLL.
* Grant-System32Permissions: Grants permissions to the "System32" directory.
* Download-And-Extract-Szip: Downloads and extracts a ZIP file named "sfile.zip".
* Download-And-Extract-Sconfigzip: Downloads and extracts a ZIP file named "sconfig.zip".
* Download-And-Extract-Svmsng: Downloads and extracts a ZIP file named "vmspolicyservice.zip".
* Configure-Svmspolicy: Executes the "vmspolicyservice.exe" tool with specific arguments.
* Configure-Svmspolicyngurl: Sends a POST request with specific data.
* Create-NewUser: Creates a new local user account.
* Configure-Firewall: Configures the Windows Firewall.
* Configure-TerminalServices: Modifies registry settings related to Terminal Services.
* Execute-Script: Executes a specified PowerShell script.
* Establish-SSHTunnels: Establishes SSH tunnels.
* Send-PostRequest: Sends a POST request to a specified URL.

The script utilizes several external tools like "takeown.exe", "icacls.exe", "netsh", "reg", and "powershell.exe" to accomplish its tasks.

The provided PowerShell code exhibits several characteristics typical of malicious behavior. It includes functions that download and extract files from specified URLs, specifically targeting DLL files associated with Remote Desktop Services. The code attempts to manipulate system services, including stopping the "Remote Desktop Services" service, replacing its DLL file with a potentially malicious version, and modifying permissions on critical system directories (like System32). 

Key actions include:
- Creating a new user with administrative privileges, which could be used for unauthorized access.
- Configuring firewall rules to allow remote desktop connections, indicating an intention to facilitate external access.
- Establishing SSH tunnels, which can be used to create covert communication channels for data exfiltration or remote control.
- Downloading additional components from external sources, which may introduce further vulnerabilities or backdoors.

The overall structure and intent of the code suggest it is designed to compromise a system's security by installing unauthorized software and enabling remote access, making it highly suspicious and indicative of malware activity.
